Furthermore, Prince Puá¹‡yabala, later on, went out to the garden with his four older brothers;

On the way, there were countless hungry ghosts with needle mouths living in the middle of the mountain. Their appearance was emaciated, like a pile of bones, and their whole bodies were ablaze. The ghosts surrounded them, invisible to others, but Prince Puá¹‡yabala first saw their appearance.
The hungry ghosts joined their palms in front of him and said to the prince:
You have great blessings and virtues, and a great reputation. You are a compassionate one.
We are tormented by hunger and thirst. We hope you will now give us some food and drink.

In our past lives, we created the cause of stinginess, so in this life we have fallen into the realm of hungry ghosts, not having had water to drink for countless thousands of years, let alone having seen food.
At that time, Prince Fuli looked up at the sky and immediately felt compassion:
How wonderful!
If I can now obtain a little food and drink from the heavens, I will use it to give to this multitude of hungry ghosts.
At that time, suddenly much food and drink descended from the heavens.
Prince Fuli then used this food to give to the hungry ghosts.
Due to the power of their past karma, the multitude of hungry ghosts were all unable to see it and said:
Prince!
We have heard that you are compassionate, why is it that you now do not give us food and drink?
The prince said:
I have had food and drink descend from the heavens and offered it to you before, why is it that you do not take the food now?
The hungry ghosts said:
Prince!
Because of the power of our past karma, we cannot see anything.
At that time, Prince Fuli had another thought:
Alas!
Stinginess is unlovable.
He then said:
If the rewards of blessings have great power, then by the power of my true words, may these hungry ghosts be able to see food and drink, and may they all be able to take and eat as they wish.
After saying this, all the hungry ghosts were able to see the food and drink, and immediately each of them transformed their faces to look like human faces.
Prince Fuli was overjoyed and gave them food and drink to their satisfaction.

The group of hungry ghosts, having obtained the food, immediately stopped feeling hungry and thirsty, their bodies became complete and strong, and they became full and robust, without any ugly appearance. They then each gave rise to a pure and joyful attitude towards Prince Fuli;
Immediately after their lives ended, they were all reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven. They circled in the sky and said to the prince:
Prince!
We have been reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven, all due to your majestic spiritual establishment.
When Prince Fuli heard these wonderful words, he was deeply delighted. He immediately went forward to the garden and discussed with his elder brothers:
What practices do the people of the world cultivate that bring the most benefit?
The one with perfect appearance said:
In this world, the practice of appearance brings the most benefit.
Why is this known?
It means that if a person is not seen by others, upon seeing them they will be delighted;
if they are not trusted and respected, upon seeing them they will trust and respect them.

Just as my former teacher, the sage, also said this: 'If one is endowed with a wonderful appearance, people will be delighted, the wonderful appearance is pleasing to behold, and one is looked up to with love;
Just as a wise person delights in the supreme Dharma and makes offerings.'
Furthermore, the one endowed with diligence said:
'Cultivating physical appearance does not bring much benefit!
Now this should be known: if a person cultivates and practices diligent conduct, they will obtain much benefit.
Why is this?
Even if one cultivates physical appearance without diligence, how can one obtain desirable fruits in this life and the next?
Those who say that physical appearance brings much benefit are foolish people, covered by the views of delusion.

As I have said, the practice of diligence can accomplish desirable results in the present life, such as farmers planting seeds, merchants making profits, officials receiving salaries, students mastering teachings, and those cultivating meditation attaining the fruits of ease and comfort, all of which are accomplished through diligence in the present life.

Moreover, this diligence can accomplish desirable results in future lives, such as being reborn in good destinies and heavenly realms, becoming greatly wealthy and free, and directly realizing liberation, all of which are accomplished through diligence in future lives.
For this reason, all merits are based on diligence.
Moreover, this diligence can overcome weakness, and if one exerts diligence, there is no small dharma that is difficult to accomplish.'
Next, the one with skillful means said:
'You good people, although you have spoken in many ways, you still cannot satisfy my mind.
Why is it so?
If one lacks skill, one will ultimately be unable to manifest accomplishments.
If one's diligence is the same as skillful work, one will be able to accomplish what one does in reality.
Therefore, one should know that if a person cultivates and creates skillful work, they will obtain much benefit.
Moreover, those who possess skill, whether kings, ministers, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, elders, or even those of lower clans and skilled workers, all come to offer their services.
Furthermore, the one endowed with wisdom said:
'You should know that for a person to cultivate and create much benefit, it is not merely a matter of physical appearance, diligence, or skill.
Why is this?
If one observes physical appearance but lacks wisdom, even if it is similar, it will not be pure and wonderful.
If one exerts diligence but lacks wisdom, even if one obtains benefits, there will be no accomplishment.
If one's craftsmanship lacks wisdom, even if one strives, one will not be able to grasp it.
Therefore, one should know that wisdom can accomplish all tasks. If a person cultivates, they will obtain much benefit.
Moreover, this wisdom can attain physical appearance, can accomplish craftsmanship, can give rise to diligence, and can obtain all the wonderful pleasures among humans.'
At that time, Prince Fuli looked at the one endowed with wisdom with a smile and said to him:
'It is so, it is so!
What you say is true.
If one lacks wisdom, one will not be able to obtain much benefit, no matter what one's physical appearance, craftsmanship, or diligence may be.
Therefore, one should know that wisdom can universally grasp all true fruits.
Good man!
However, if this wisdom lacks the power of blessings, then whatever one does will also not be accomplished.
Therefore, one should truly know that if a person cultivates blessings, they will obtain much benefit.
Why is it so?
Merit is a pure and single fruit, merit is a fruit of radiance, merit is a desirable fruit, merit is a fruit of satisfaction.
I cannot fully explain the merits of such meritorious fruits. Now, in order to enlighten you, I will speak a little about the gate of merit. Listen well.

Due to having merit, one can obtain physical appearance. Merit is endowed with diligence. Merit obtains auspiciousness and also attains great wealth. Merit is endowed with wisdom. Merit can sing the merits of the true Dharma. Merit is endowed with sharpness. Merit roams the right path. Merit is born into a noble family. Merit obtains past mindfulness. Merit is endowed with fame. Merit perfects moral conduct. Merit can give. Merit always obtains unimpaired faculties through the power of merit. Merit is always joyful. The meritorious are always honored by the wise. Merit perfects all powers. Merit always encounters good friends and acquaintances. The power of merit can accomplish all activities - namely, if one plows and plants fields, or if one engages in commerce seeking profit, one can accomplish much with little effort and greatly accumulate wealth and freedom.
The meritorious are able to have clothing, food, precious treasures, and everything they need rain down from the sky at will, and they experience happiness according to their wishes.
The meritorious obtain desirable and wonderful houses;
In the present life and in other lives, they will always obtain beautiful wives, daughters, relatives, and wealth, grains, and so forth.
The ground where the meritorious walk will naturally be free from thorns, sand, and gravel, and will be level and stable;
The meritorious will also obtain a vast physical appearance;
If there are sick people, when the meritorious touch them with their hands, the illness will be relieved according to the severity;
Moreover, wherever the meritorious touch people, they will be able to produce food, drink, clothing, precious treasures, wealth, and grains, providing them without end;
The meritorious will always be guarded and protected by gods, dragons, yakshas, rakshasas, and ghosts, just as the spirits protect the seedlings during the rainy season;
The meritorious will always be respected and loved by many people;
Merit has good reputation, and the meritorious are praised by others;
The meritorious are always able to possess all wholesome dharmas;
The words of the meritorious are trusted and obeyed by others;
The meritorious always obtain a radiant and lovely appearance;
The fortunate always emit a subtle and wonderful Brahma voice;
The fortunate have naturally soft limbs;
The fortunate always speak wonderful and good words;
The fortunate always meet with good friends and wise people, and their retinue is indestructible;
The fortunate are without illness;
The fortunate are loved by others;
The fortunate obtain wealth and profit;
The fortunate are courageous.
Moreover, the greatly fortunate become human kings, complete in all aspects, free from all illnesses;
The fortunate always obtain prosperity that is indestructible;
The fortunate obtain the treasures of the turning wheel, complete with the seven treasures;
The fortunate are able to travel through the sky;

The fortunate are always born in good destinies;
The fortunate abandon evil destinies;
The fortunate always obtain the most difficult to obtain delightful and wonderful flowers;
The fortunate accomplish what they set out to do;
The fortunate are able to illuminate the world;
The fortunate are always righteously believed and worshipped by gods, humans, and asuras.'
When the prince spoke of these matters of blessings, his four elder brothers had different views and did not practice the same. Then the prince said again:
'I now wish to secretly go to another country with my elder brothers and, wherever we stay, verify these matters.
Are there more people who cultivate evil because of their appearance,
Or are there more people who cultivate evil because of their diligence, skill, wisdom, or blessings?'
At that time, the four elder brothers, having heard his words, all followed him and did not again inform their father, the king. They then went to another country.
Having entered a country, they changed their attire and each sought a place to stay.

The one endowed with perfect physical appearance, due to having a wonderful appearance, is looked at by people, and all give rise to a delighted mind, and accordingly obtain wealth and abundance, and enjoy the resources for sustenance.
The one endowed with perfect diligence, due to having courageous strength, is able to take something;

and suddenly sees a great swift-flowing river, deep and wide, terrifying, with a very large sandalwood tree in it. The diligent one takes the tree, trades it for profit, obtains wealth and abundance, and enjoys the resources for sustenance.
The one endowed with perfect craftsmanship, by the power of craftsmanship, does various things as appropriate, and by obtaining wealth and abundance, enjoys the resources for sustenance.

The one endowed with perfect wisdom, due to having skillful wisdom, is able to defeat superior enemies, and is also able to associate with those who have wealth and power, delights their minds and causes them to give rise to joy, and accordingly obtains clothing, ornaments, and treasures, and as he pleases, enjoys the resources for sustenance.
At that time, Prince Fuli, following his own superior blessings and great majestic virtue, traveled around performing beneficial and meritorious deeds.

One day, he happened to pass by a poor man's house, and entered it. Due to the power of the prince's blessings, the house suddenly had a vast and auspicious appearance of excellence, with gold, jewels, wealth, and grain filling all around.
At that time, the poor man, seeing this, was startled, delighted, and thought:
'Such things have never happened before. What is the cause of this?
Where did it come from?
Could it be that this person came to my house, and it is due to his majestic power that this has occurred?'
He also thought:
'In the past, I suffered extreme poverty, but now I have gained victory and everything is abundant. It must be due to this person coming here that auspicious signs have appeared in my house.
This person has great blessings and a great reputation. I should respect and make offerings to him.'
Thus, they respectfully followed him without interruption.
The prince brought prosperity and happiness to the poor man's house, and later on, the fame spread everywhere:
In a certain house, which was formerly very poor, a strange person came and entered the house. Because of his power, auspicious signs suddenly appeared in the house.
Having heard this, the people all developed faith and respect towards Prince Puá¹‡yabala, and they praised him together, saying:
How wonderful!
The superior merit has great power!

Moreover, because of the power of Prince Puá¹‡yabala's merit, in that place, flower trees and fruit trees bloomed and bore fruit on time, and sweet rain sprinkled everywhere, causing the seeds to grow and flourish.
At that time, the people deeply loved Prince Puá¹‡yabala and all came to look up to him.
At that time, the prince, in order to universally gather the minds of those who came, had this thought:
'How wonderful!
Now in my house, I can obtain all precious treasures, various kinds of entertainment, and all kinds of wonderful and delightful objects, to provide for those who come and make them complete.'
When he had this thought, all the precious treasures and so forth appeared as if in response, all abundant.
At that time, the multitude of people marveled and exclaimed:
'How strange!
Great blessings are the sweet fruits.'
They all gave rise to respect for the prince.

At that time, the prince then, for the people, according to their needs, equally embraced them with the four means of gathering disciples, and harmoniously united them, namely, the same giving, kind speech, beneficial conduct, and sharing the same purpose.
Because of this, his reputation was widely known in all the countries, towns, and villages.
Later, the prince gradually reached a country, where he saw the king punishing a good doctor. He ordered the prison official to break the man's body and cut off his hands and feet.
The blood flowed profusely, and the pain was excruciating. At that time, the man being punished, upon seeing the prince, let out a great cry of suffering and said in tears:
'Sir!
Save me!
Sir!
Save me!'
The prince was immediately moved by this and thought to himself:
'What expedient means can I use to save this man's suffering?'
As he was thinking this, he suddenly had an insight: 'By the power of the merit I have accumulated and the good deeds I have done, I can see this in the world.
' Having thought this, his compassionate heart was stirred, and he immediately broke his own body, releasing much blood, which he gave to the man to drink, and his suffering was relieved.

The prince saw that the man's hands and feet had been cut off and he was in great pain. He then took a sharp knife, cut off his own hands and feet, and placed them where the man's hands and feet had been cut off.
At that time, the prince observed the sky and universally gave rise to a compassionate mind towards all beings. He then made a vast and true vow, saying:

In this life, I have never committed even the slightest unwholesome karma. If what I say is true, may this man's hands and feet, where they were cut off, immediately join together at the joints, and may he be restored to his former state.
As soon as he spoke these words, the man's limbs joined together, and his body was completely healed, restored to its former state.
Seeing this, the prince's wishes were fulfilled, and he thought:
Through my diligence and effort, what I have done has been accomplished. I have saved this man from suffering by giving him my own blood.
I have cut off my own hands and feet to continue his limbs.
And by the power of true and great vows, may their bodies and lives be completely restored as before.

May I, with this supreme wholesome root, accomplish the fruit of unsurpassed perfect supreme enlightenment, and may I use the flavor of the Dharma to bestow it upon them, ultimately causing them to abide in the bliss of nirvana.'
When he made this vow, the entire earth shook in six ways, and the palace of Indra in the Heaven of the Thirty-three also trembled.
At that time, the lord of the Heaven of the Thirty-three immediately thought to himself:
'What is the significance of this event?
' And he further observed and saw that Prince Fuli was performing the most supreme and extremely difficult deed, and he marveled at his joy.
He also thought:
'Now, this one of great authority and virtue, having done this difficult deed, what does he seek?
I should now go and verify the reason.'
He then transformed himself into the appearance of a brahmin and descended from heaven, standing before the prince and saying:
'Prince!
I saw you cut off your own hands and feet just now. What were you doing that for?'
The prince replied:
'Good sir!
If others are in pain, then I am in pain;
if others are happy, then I am happy.

Therefore, when I saw a person being punished just now, in great pain, I then, by the power of truth, abandoned my own hands and feet, filling in the places where his limbs were cut off. By the sincerity of my vow, he recovered as before.'
At that time, the Lord of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, even more amazed, immediately returned to his original form and said to the prince:
'Are you not now abandoning your own body because of an unreal mind, or because of seeking something different, or because of turning back?'
The prince said:
'Lord of the Heaven of the Thirty-three!
The hands and feet of my own body that I have abandoned are not with an unreal mind, nor am I seeking anything different, nor am I turning back.'

'Lord of the gods!

The prince then gave rise to a mind of loving-kindness towards all beings, observed the four directions, and with the power of true vows, spoke a verse, saying:
If what I say is true, and I am bound by craving for my own body;
If it is true and irreversible now, may my body be as it was before.
Having spoken this verse, the prince's body immediately recovered.
